headline.main: Pictures From the Week in Business, Dec. 7

snippet: Steinway & Sons has signed a tentative agreement to sell its 16-story building in Manhattan, including its piano showroom that captivates world-class musicians and amateurs alike.
abstract: Steinway & Sons has signed a tentative agreement to sell its historic 16-story building in Manhattan, including its celebrated piano showroom; Michael T Sweeney, chief executive of Steinway Musical Instruments, says that the company was losing about $5 million a year on the famous Beaux-Arts building build in 1925 and given landmark status in 2001.

headline.main: Fate Unclear for Ornate Piano Showroom
headline.print_headline: Fate Unclear for Ornate Piano Showroom

snippet: The latest version of iTunes, known as iTunes 11, has been lauded for its spare design, but some people may miss elements that have disappeared. The good news is that some are just hidden or renamed and you can get them back easily.
abstract: The latest version of iTunes, known as iTunes 11, has been lauded for its spare design, but some people may miss elements that have disappeared. The good news is that some are just hidden or renamed and you can get them back easily.

headline.main: How to Restore Old iTunes Features to New iTunes

snippet: Here is a proposal for a new holiday, observed on Dec. 11, when people take a moment to make sure they’re doing enough to protect themselves from investment fraud.
abstract: Paul Sullivan Wealth Matters column proposes new holiday, observed on Dec 11, when people take a moment to think about ways to protect themselves from investment fraud.

snippet: A controversial Facebook post by Netflix's chief executive shows how the Internet age has presented new challenges for defining what is "fair disclosure." | Diamondback Capital Management, which was caught up in the government's insider trading in...
abstract: A controversial Facebook post by Netflix's chief executive shows how the Internet age has presented new challenges for defining what is "fair disclosure." | Diamondback Capital Management, which was caught up in the government's insider trading investigation, is shutting down. | Public shareholders don't always get a say in deals. | David Kostman, a former head of Lehman Brothers' global Internet group, recently returned to Wall Street -- serving up lunch at Goldman Sachs.
